title: 103_hr2328
content: The "Public Lands Corps Act of 1993" is cited as the short title for this Act. Congressional findings and purpose are outlined in the following sections. The Congress finds that conserving natural and cultural resources through a Public Lands Corps can benefit young men and women by providing education and work opportunities, furthering their understanding of resources, and benefiting the economy and environment. Many public lands and Indian reservations require labor-intensive rehabilitation and restoration. The Public Lands Corps aims to perform cost-effective conservation work on public and Indian lands that cannot be done by existing personnel. Youth conservation corps have a good track record of restoring and maintaining facilities in partnership with government agencies. The purpose is to assist in research, education, and improvement of these lands. The Public Lands Corps aims to assist government and tribal land managing agencies in research and education tasks related to natural and cultural resources on public lands. It also aims to expose young individuals to public service and conservation careers, while expanding educational opportunities for participants. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines key terms such as "Corps" as the Public Lands Corps, "public lands" as lands owned or administered by the United States, and "qualified youth or conservation corps" as programs offering work for individuals aged 16-25 in natural or cultural settings. The term "Indian tribe" refers to any group recognized as such by the Secretary of the Interior, including Native village corporations and groups established under the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act. "Indian" is defined as a member of an Indian tribe, and "Indian lands" are real property owned or held in trust by an Indian tribe. The term "Indian lands" refers to real property owned by an Indian tribe, held in trust by the United States, or subject to restrictions on alienation. The term "State" includes various regions within the United States. A "conservation, restoration, or rehabilitation project" involves preserving natural, cultural, historic, archaeological, recreational, or scenic resources. The Public Lands Corps Program is established. Establishment of Public Lands Corps in the Department of the Interior and Agriculture for young men and women aged 16-25. Enrollees must be U.S. citizens or residents, have a high school diploma or equivalent, and not have dropped out of school. Enrollees are exempt from civil service laws. The Public Lands Corps allows young men and women aged 16-25 to work on conservation projects on public or Indian lands. The Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture can contract with qualified youth or conservation corps for these projects, prioritizing those with long-term public benefits. Under this Act, projects on public or Indian lands must provide long-term public benefits, instill a work ethic in participants, be labor-intensive, prompt, and offer educational opportunities. Projects must comply with land management laws and policies. The Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture can provide quarters for Conservation Centers. The Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture are authorized to provide services and facilities for conservation programs, including establishing conservation centers with logistical support from the military. Basic standards for health, nutrition, sanitation, and safety must be maintained at these centers. The Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture are authorized to establish conservation centers with basic standards for health, nutrition, sanitation, and safety enforced through contracts with government agencies and private organizations. SEC. 5. RESOURCE ASSISTANTS. The Resource Assistant Program authorizes the placement of qualified college students or recent graduates in Federal land managing agencies to conduct research or technical functions. Participants are recruited from colleges nationwide, with a focus on diversity. The program aims to serve two purposes. The Resource Assistant Program aims to augment the workforce of Federal land managing agencies by utilizing college students and recent graduates, while also providing exposure to potential career opportunities in conservation agencies. Existing nonprofit organizations may be utilized to fulfill program requirements, and participating organizations are expected to contribute to funding expenses. Private Sources of Funding: Participating nonprofit organizations must contribute 25% of the total costs for each intern in the Resource Assistant program from private funding. They are also required to submit an annual report evaluating the program's impact on the agency's mission. SEC. 6. Living allowances and terms of service for participants. Living allowances and terms of service are provided to participants in the Public Lands Corps and Resource Assistants. The living allowance should not exceed the maximum established for participants in the national service program. Participants agree to a term of service determined by the Secretary of the Interior or Agriculture, consistent with the national service program requirements. SEC. 7. EDUCATIONAL BENEFITS OR AWARDS FOR PARTICIPANTS. Participants in the Public Lands Corps and Resource Assistants may be eligible for national service awards under the National and Community Service Act of 1990. The Secretary of the Interior or Agriculture will establish requirements for eligibility. Benefits and awards usage and amounts will be determined accordingly. Borrowers in the program may receive forbearance on Stafford Loans under the Higher Education Act of 1965. Upon written request, a lender must grant forbearance to borrowers who are participants in the Public Lands Corps or Resource Assistants program, in accordance with regulations set by the Secretary of Education. This forbearance is applicable during the borrower's service as a participant or Resource Assistant, and when eligible for post-service educational benefits or awards. SEC. 8. NONDISPLACEMENT. The nondisplacement requirements of the National and Community Service Act of 1990 shall apply to all activities of the Public Lands Corps and qualified youth or conservation corps under this Act. SEC. 9. FUNDING. Cost Sharing: The Secretary of the Interior and the Secretary of Agriculture can pay up to 75% of project costs on public lands by qualified youth or conservation corps. The remaining 25% can come from nonfederal sources. No cost sharing is required for projects on Indian lands. Additionally, a foundation associated with a Federal land managing agency may contribute to the costs of projects by the Public Lands Corps. The Public Lands Corps, established under this Act, does not require cost sharing for projects. The Secretary of the Interior and the Secretary of Agriculture can receive funds under the National and Community Service Act for programs, without restrictions. Authorization of necessary appropriations is provided to carry out this Act.
